ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

VENTILATION IN UNDERGROUND CAR PARKS


    1. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for National Development what enforcement policy is in place to ensure that the air ventilation systems of underground car parks are functioning properly.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, building regulations require all basement car parks to have mechanical ventilation systems providing at least six air changes per hour. This is comparable to standards adopted by other countries.

    Owners and management corporations of buildings are required to maintain and keep their car park mechanical ventilation systems in good working condition.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Can I ask the Minister which department in his Ministry is in charge of enforcing such regulations to maintain the air quality designed into the air ventilation systems?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Building Control Division of my Ministry is in charge of enforcing the regulations governing any violation of these rules.

CLEANLINESS IN HDB ESTATES
(Effects of manpower shortage)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chew Heng Ching ---

    2. To ask the Minister for National Development if the standard of cleanliness in Housing and Development Board estates has suffered as a result of cleaning contractors facing manpower shortage; and, if so, what measures the HDB will take to overcome the problem.

     Encik Zulkifli bin Mohammed (Eunos GRC): Question No. 2, Sir.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are presently 32 conservancy con-

Column: 140

tractors holding contracts for the cleaning of HDB housing estates. 18 of these contractors commenced their contract on 1 April 1989. In the first two weeks of April some contractors were short of manpower and equipment. This resulted in a temporary drop in standard of cleanliness in some HDB housing estates. To correct the situation, HDB mobilized its own workers and other conservancy contractors to spruce up the affected estates. HDB also increased daily site supervision to identify problem areas and to take immediate corrective action. As a result, Sir, the standard of cleanliness in HDB estates is now back to normal. HDB, however, will continue to monitor the performance of the contractors closely and will not hesitate to impose penalties against those who do not carry out their contracts properly.

    Besides these measures, I would also like to call on residents in the public housing estates to cooperate with HDB's efforts to maintain a clean environment. Residents should not litter the common areas. Bulky refuse should not be abandoned along common corridors or at lift landings. If necessary, residents should seek HDB's assistance in disposing of such bulky refuse.

    With more residents' cooperation, the task of keeping the housing estates clean would be achievable at a lower cost to everybody.

SREE NARAYANA MISSION HOME
(Steps to prevent recurrence of food poisoning)


    4. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry has established the cause of the outbreak of food poisoning at the Sree Narayana Mission Home for the Aged Sick; and what steps his Ministry has taken to prevent the recurrence of such incidents.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister of the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The recent outbreak of diarrhoea at the Sree Narayana Home was caused by the dysentery bacteria, Shigella. A total of 68 inmates and two ward attendants came down with diarrhoea between 28th April and 15th May 1989. A 78-year old inmate died on 4th May 1989.

    Sir, the outbreak is likely to have been caused by food prepared by the Home. The food could have been contaminated by one of the inmates who had helped in the kitchen. The inmate could have earlier been infected with dysentery bacteria after eating food brought in from outside and became a transient carrier.

    The Sree Narayana Home was well maintained and the general sanitation, including toilets, was satisfactory. The kitchen in the Home was clean. Food samples taken from meals prepared by the Home, during investigations, were found to be free from dysentery germs. The Home's cooks and their assistants were medically screened and they were also found to be free from dysentery infection.

    Sir, the two key factors in the prevention of outbreaks of food borne diseases in

Column: 142

Homes for the aged and the destitutes are a high standard of environmental sanitation and good personal hygiene. Managements should avoid enlisting the help of inmates in food preparation and in the kitchen. They should also be on the look-out for diarrhoeal cases and isolate them from the rest of the inmates and then treat them.

    As a routine, officers from my Ministry carry out checks to ensure that the environmental sanitation in Homes for the aged and the destitutes are satisfactorily maintained.

FOOD POISONING
(Increase in)


    5. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for the Environment if he will explain the significant increase in the number of food poisoning cases reported to his Ministry in 1988 compared with those in previous years; and what measures are being taken to contain the problem.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (for the Minister for the Environment): Sir, 191 cases of food poisoning were reported in 1988 as compared with 135 in 1987 and 91 in 1986. The majority of these food poisoning reports were made by members of the public to my Ministry.

    Inspections of eating establishments carried out by my Ministry throughout the year, however, showed that there has not been a deterioration in food hygiene standards amongst food handlers in 1988. The number of contraventions on food and personal hygiene by food vendors was less in 1988, 6.7% of premises inspected compared to 9.1% of premises inspected in 1987. My Ministry, however, will continue to step up checks against all food vendors in food establishments.

    Sir, every licensed food establishment is placed on a schedule of inspection. On an average, eating establishments and food stalls are checked once a month. Those with poorer records are inspected more than once a month.

    My Ministry takes a very serious view against improper practices of food and personal hygiene amongst food vendors.

Column: 143

Every restaurant manager, every eating house proprietor, every hawker, food caterer and anyone involved in the sale of food must be fully responsible and accountable for the standard of hygiene of food sold by him and the cleanliness of the premises where food is prepared.

    Sir, since September 1987 licensees of eating establishments, including hawkers, are given demerit points whenever they are convicted of any food hygiene offences. Those who have accumulated 12 points within 12 months will have their licences suspended for two weeks. And if they continue to commit further offences, their licences may be revoked.

    My Ministry is in the process of amending the Environmental Public Health (Food Handlers) Regulations and the Environmental Public Health (Food Establishments) Regulations to introduce tighter control measures, including heavier penalties against recalcitrant hawkers and restaurant operators. The amended Regulations will be ready in three to four months' time.

    Sir, we will study the systems of countries with high hygiene standards, such as Japan, to learn how to upgrade the education of food handlers and our supervision of food handling. Food vendors in Singapore must learn about food and personal hygiene and they must adopt a sense of responsibility to consumers by dropping their old and dirty habits and picking up clean ones.

    My Ministry is very pleased to note that there is today a greater awareness amongst members of the public on food hygiene and food poisoning, brought about by wider publicity given on these topics by the press media last year. Members of the public are now more inclined to report to the Ministry whenever they come down with diarrhoea or other symptoms of food poisoning when they consume food bought from eating establishments. Health inspectors from my Ministry will carry out full investigations into every complaint and report of food poisoning made by members of the public to my Ministry.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, Changi Airport's Second Passenger Terminal Building is scheduled for completion by the second half of 1990. TEO SOH LUNG
(Reasons for continued detention)


    10. Dr Lee Siew-Choh asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the reasons for Teo Soh Lung's continued detention when the others have been released.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Government has explained on many occasions, a decision on whether a detainee should be released earlier than the expiry of the detention order or be in continued detention depends on the assessment of the Internal Security Department on whether the detainee has responded positively to rehabilitation and whether he is likely to reinvolve himself in subversive activities and pose a security threat upon release. ISD's current assessment is that Teo Soh Lung is not suitable for early release.

    In considering whether to release a detainee, the Government also takes into consideration reports of the Advisory Board constituted under the Internal Security Act. Teo, together with three other detainees, namely, Chng Suan Tze, Kevin De Souza and Wong Souk Yee, had made representations to the Advisory Board on 20th January 1989. While the Board recommended that consideration can be given for the early release of Chng Suan Tze, Kevin De Souza and Wong Souk Yee, it made no recommendation for Teo's early release. Chng Suan Tze, Kevin De Souza and Wong Souk Yee were thus released on 11th March 1989.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Does the Minister agree that in the first statement the ISD issued when Teo Soh Lung was released, it was said that she would no longer pose a threat to the security of Singapore?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the statement with me but she was arrested in May 1987 and released on certain conditions and a press statement was issued. Her present detention order is the result of her rearrest in 1988.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Was it not said that she was rearrested because of her public statement?

Column: 148



     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would urge the Member to carefully read the statements which have been issued by the Government. When she was rearrested together with the others, it was pointed out that the contents of her press statement gave rise to the conclusion that she and the others were likely to resume their subversive activities.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Is it not true, Sir, that when the other three were released they had forgone the application for the habeas corpus and that Teo Soh Lung had not?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, the Member is repeating claims of others that Teo Soh Lung is in continued detention because she pressed on with her habeas corpus case whilst the other three, Wong Souk Yee, Kevin De Souza and Chng Suan Tze, were released because they dropped their habaes corpus cases. This is totally untrue. In the first case, the three of them withdrew their cases on 3rd March. But the Advisory Board had submitted its report recommending their early release before they withdrew their cases. In other words, the Government's decision was based on the Advisory Board's recommendation which had recommended theirearly release before they withdrew their cases.

    Secondly, let me also point out the fallacy of that view because Vincent Cheng who never brought any habeas corpus proceedings is still in detention. Thirdly, Patrick Seong was released in May 1988 even though his case was still before the courts.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: How does the Minister distinghish Teo Soh Lung's case from the case of the other three who were released?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, it must be obvious from my answer that it depended on the security assessment by the Internal Security Department.

ARREST OF ILLEGAL INDIAN FOREIGN WORKERS
(Effects of, on relationship with India)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong ---

    11. To ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the relationship between

Column: 149

Singapore and India has deteriorated as a result of the recent arrest, conviction and sentence of certain Indian foreign workers and, if so, whether the situation will escalate for the worse.

     Mr Chandra Das: Question No. 11, Sir.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, bilateral relations between Singapore and India are good. In the past few years, our bilateral relations have been strengthened based on mutual respect for each other's sovereignty and non-interference in each other's internal affairs.

    Singapore has long had a problem with illegal immigrants. Given Singapore's size and scarce resources, we have no choice but to take tough measures to curb the number of illegal immigrants in Singapore. As there was no effective means to deter the increase in the number of illegal immigrants and overstayers, the Immigration Act was amended this year to provide for stronger punishment against them. The new amendment to the Immigration Act was debated in Parliament on 26th January this year. The Immigration (Amendment) Act came into effect on 31st March 1989. The law applies to all foreigners irrespective of nationality and the new penalties apply to those who enter Singapore illegally or overstay for more than 90 days.

    The amended Immigration law provides for caning of illegal immigrants and overstayers. Caning is a deterrent punishment provided for in several of Singapore's laws. For example, the Misuse of Drugs Act, the Penal Code and the Vandalism Act provide caning for offences like trafficking in controlled drugs, robbery and vandalism. I have asked the Clerk to distribute a table (Cols. 227 - 230) showing the details of some of the offences which attract caning.

    Sentencing comes under the domain of our courts and will have to be carried out by due process of law. For example, in 1987, 602 prisoners were caned, of whom 487 were Singapore nationals and 115 were non-nationals, among whom were 1 Indian, 1 Chinese and 11 Thai nationals. In

Column: 150
